personally I would use a timer.
[/quote]This isn’t shitty VB…

…I could of sworn Java has numerous timing methods, i.e java.util.Timer.[/quote]

Yar, http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/Timer.html
And http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/swing/Timer.html
etc.

item.title: Timing Question
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

that code up there should have gave you a heap exception.

[code]
public void run()
{
long toRemove = 0;

while(true)
{
	if(chatText != null && !chatText.equals("") && toRemove == 0)
	{
		toRemove = System.currentTimeMillis() + 5000;
	}
	else if(toRemove >= System.currentTimeMillis())
	{
		toRemove = 0;
		chatText = "";
	}
}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Timing Question
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

An alternate to Coder xynt

private void wait(int ms) { long start = System.currentTimeMillis(); while((System.currentTimeMillis()) - start) <= ms) Thread.yield(); }

Read full topic

item.title: Timing Question
item.dc:creator: @d_sign d_sign
item.description:
@d_sign wrote:

Hey everyone.
I’m making a simple game, where you can type things and they appear above you, but I want them to disappear after a short time.
Here’s what I’m trying to use…

	public void run ()
	{
		
		Thread.currentThread().setPriority(Thread.MIN_PRIORITY);


		while (true)
		{
                        if(chatText != ""){
                            Thread chatTh = new Thread(this);
                            chatTh.start();
                            try
                                {
                                chatTh.sleep(5000);
                                }
                                catch (Exception e) {}
                            chatText = new String("");
                            }

But this isn’t working…does Java have like a wait() function?

Thanks

Read full topic
